title: Giant fidget spinner, 6020 bearing and M27 + M10 nuts

description.text:
Hello all,

This is my first big creation that I share here, I made them in Fusion 360

This is my biggest fidget spinner design. I make this to fit to the maximum size of my 3D printer. (220220250 printer)

I used a 6020 bearing, 4 M27 nuts and 8 M10 (2 per hole).
It's printed in ABS and acetone vapor smoothed, all fit tight and put in place with hammer

The entire thing weights 2kg, that's for why I make a handle to grab them easily( the handle is not centered because like this it's easier to put hand inside)

I hope you like them!

https://youtu.be/ywVrd-v9ssE

Printer:

Zonestar D805R2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.20

Infill:

30%

Notes:

Simple design, no support needed, I ised Raft for the body and nothing for the handle.
I made them in ABS with 30% infill

I smoothed all with acetone vapor bath, and then I put bearing and nuts inside with hammer,
The handle is in 2 piece that can be removed easily
I designed them in Fusion 360

description.text:
Minimalist camera mount for the CM275T I used for the Ultralight Whoop build.
This camera gets too hot to mount using loom-bands so I came up with this.

Just stick it between the camera and the VTX (it's a tight fit) then heat up the ends with a lighter and bend them upwards to create little 'hooks' to attach your loom band to.
This prevents the loom band from melting because of the heat this AIO produces.

author: guibail

description.text: A wall mounted guitar hanger scale 2500%

This what I use on my D-bot for the Z axis.
I'm using an heavy 314x314x4mm aluminium bed, and with the original Spauda's build I had some issues with auto bed leveling and ringing.

This setup use almost the same materials than the original Spauda's D-Bot requieres except some specific screws and PC wheels instead of the black ones.

The concept is to use "wheel tensionners" to push on the verticals V-slot. I didn't try it with black wheels but I'm convinced that he pressure will damage them. I highly recommend to use PC wheels. The "wheel tensionners" give 2 advantages :
-It kills the bed wiggles (and so ringing)
-and you can level the back and the front of the bed by adjusting the wheels pressures.

Part of my D-Bot Upgrades collection.

Parts needed

From the original build:
-2 motor mount bracket and the hardware it needs
-6 3x3_plate and the hardware it needs
-6 Corner_bracket and the hardware it needs
-Hardware needed for the lead screw brackets (only the hardware, not the printed part)

Extra Hardware:
-8 PC mini wheels (and 16 bearings)
-8 M5x25mm screws (for the wheels)
-8 M5x16mm screws or longer (for the tensionners)
-8 M5x8mm flat head screws (to fix the tensionners to the rails)
-8 M5 square or T-nuts (to fix the tensionners to the rails)
-16 M5 nylock nuts (to hold the wheels and for the tensionners)
-8 M3 washers (to plug into the wheel holder's holes where the tensionners will push)

You also need to cut the original K V-slot (it is used to hold the Z motor in the original build) 10mm shorter than N/M rails (i.e 453mm in my case, but do your homework and take measurment before any cut)

Extra prints:
-8 WheelTensioner part
-2 BackWheelHolder part
-2 FrontWheelHolder part
-2 LeadScrewBracketOffset part (those have the same offset than the Spauda's motor mounts)

Optionnal:
For the bed level marks :
-4 M5x8mm flat head screw
-4 M5 square or T-nuts
-1 BedLevelMark_Part1
-1 BedLevelMark_Part2

For the front lead screw :
-2 M5x10mm
-2 M5x16 or longer
-4 M5 washers
-2 M5 square or T-nuts
-a 20x20 V-slot off-cut (lenght is not important)
-2 20x20_VslotBracket
-2 20x20_endcap

Build Instruction

The Printer Frame
First you must get a perfectly square structure. Follow the Spauda's build guide to adjust the top of the frame. Then you must get the rails A/B and C/D parallel to each others. take the top of the frame as reference and adjust distances at the bottom of the frame. Once you get all rails parallels take time to tight every screws. Center and fix the motor mounts on M and L rails.

The Bed Frame
Follow the Spauda's build guide for the back of the bed frame. For the front of the frame use the K rail (cutted 10mm shorter than N/M rails), 2 3x3 plates, 2 corner brackets and center everything. I recommand to build it on a flat surface to get a plane geometry. I you have a 20x20 v-slot cut-off add it on K rail with the 2 20x20_VslotBracket. Center and fix the lead screw brackets on K and Q rails.

The Wheel Tensioners
Don't fix the wheels in the wheel Holders yet.
To simplify the build glue the M3 washers into holes of the wheel holders. Fit the wheel holders to the end of the V-slot and fix every tensioners as close as possible of the wheel holders. Thigh them firmly. Set every m5x16mm screw with nylock nut on all tensioners. Plug back the wheel holders on V-slot and insert all the bed frame into the printer frame (use something to hold it at mid height). Now you can insert the wheels into the wheel holders and fix them with M5x25mm screws and nylock nuts.
Even not tight, the bed shouldn't be able to move out the frame now.
Add the threaten rods.

Tuning
Start to tension each wheels symetricaly until each wheel get a good contact with the rails.
Get the bed height close to the homing position, it is better to tune at top or bottom of the frame than at mid height.
Regularly try to rotate the bed a bit on Y axis, and keep add tension to wheels until the bed can't rotate anymore. Finally you can use a level along the X axis and adjust pressures to get a bed frame perfectly horizontal. Then test it on the full Z run and keep on adjustements until you get the perfect setup.

comments.text: Hi that is great! bur i still try to understand what are those pc wheel and where can we found these
comments.author: Mendel_2

comments.text:
Hi
PC is for polycarbonate, this is the white wheels. They are also called Xtreme V wheels. Contrary to the black ones, those wheels take no bumps with the pressure.
It might also work with the black ones, but as it uses some tensions for the pre-leveling, I recommend to use PC ones.
comments.author: Mendel_2

comments.text: I think there may be an error in your measurements. N and M in a typical kit are 463mm. You indicate 453mm as a target length by subtracting 10mm from this. However, the thickness of the BackWheelHolder.stl base plate that the v-slot presses against is ~ 7mm (verified in Slic3r and a digital caliper). 7 * 2 = 14mm. So a 453mm 2040 extrusion with both wheel holders on measures ~ 467mm which won't fit.
comments.author: denos

comments.text:
Hello
Watch out mate, I never said to cut the 2040 Q rail which is 448mm long ( 448+14=462 to fit in 463mm opening size).
I talk about the 2020 K rail, which in the original kit is used to old the Z motor. If you take measurments of the base of the 2020 wheelHolder, you'll get 4.25mm ( 553 + 8.5 =560.5 which will also fit).
I made it in order to not buy more V-slot, but if you plan to use only 2040 rails, take Q rail as reference without any lenght reduction.
GL
comments.author: denos

comments.text: Ok, that makes sense. I have easy access to 2040 and wanted one for the front. I'll cut the piece at 448mm. Thanks again!

comments.text:
Tu dois parler de celles qui maintiennent les tensionneurs sur le rail. Trop long c'est effectivement problematique parce qu'il faut bien les serrer. comments.author: Barkie

comments.text:
Hello again.
I just tought about something, as this setup pre-level the bed around the Y axis, you should make all the tuning without the treathen rods. Find a way to hold your bed frame along the center of the Y axis for all the tuning steps, and then set the threaten rods on the gravity center along X axis (probably a bit before the middle, depending on your bed weight).
I have to admit that Idk how it is gonna react. The danger is that a diffence of pressures at front and back generate unwished friction....But! if you use a 20x40 instead of a 20x20 for the front of the frame, the larger space between the wheels might fight that risk. Please let me know how it goes.
comments.author: Barkie

comments.text:
Hello.
Yes it should also work with the 200x300 bed setup.
If you want to still have the Z motors along the Y axis, all you gonna need is an extra V-slot, so yes you'd better go for a 20x40 one (same as the Q one indeed). That's all for the hardware.
For the printed parts, in your case you won't need to print the offseted lead screw brackets, you can use the original one's. Then you won't need the FrontWheelHolders, instead print 4 BackWheelHolders.
Finally for the bed frame you can use 8 Corner_Brackets instead of 6, and about the 3x3_plate I guess that you will be able to put only 6 because of the bed_holder parts...so I'ld advise to start w/ 6 build the frame and see if you can put 2 mores...but that's not really important.
With a 20x40 rail you won't need the end caps and the VslotBracket parts.

title: Oven control panel electronics case, Wujiang Sigmatron / 316222807

description.text:
Did part of your oven break? Was it some random plastic thing that holds the electronics for the control panel in place? It turns out that it's an important part, and you can't purchase the plastic thing by itself. But you can easily print a new one for way cheap, because some random guy on the internet (me) modeled it.

Print this using ABS, since it has a much higher glass transition temperature (~105 C). If you use something with a lower glass transition temperature like PLA (~65 C), the plastic is likely to warp since it can get quite hot where the control panel is, depending on your oven model.

description.text:
This is a fidget spinner toy using fishing weights instead of bearings as counter weights. It is similar to an earlier version, but the weights are a bit further out on the radius, so it spins even more efficiently. The weights are 16 grams each, while standard bearings weight 11 grams. With weights instead of bearings, the fidget spins more than twice as long. (This is not a rigorous comparison. There may be differences in bearings that are not accounted for.)

Each cap has a pair of tabs that slide into the tabs of the other cap. There is a small (~1mm) shoulder on the cap to prevent interference with the spinner.

A standard 608ZZ Shielded 8x22x7 Miniature Ball Bearing is used in the center.

The weights are barrel shaped and measure ~16mm long by 14mm at the widest part of the "barrel."

print_settings.Notes:: I added supports between the wheels on the bottom of the car to help the wheels print. You can cut them off.

description.text:
A 1/100 scale model of a German WWII railcar from an armored train. These cars were used as the second car in the train. It would push an empty flatcar ahead of it to set off mines and it would be followed by a special car carrying a small tank. That car had a built in ramp in the front that fit under the sloped edge of this car. That car will be my next release.

title: Easy and Quick print Pokeball Pokemon

description.text:
I've been wanting an easy/quick print Pokeball for a while and wasn't satisfied with anything on Thingiverse. They were all either too complicated or didn't look good. TheDesignerd's spinner had good looking Pokeballs with a simple design. I just took his model and changed it so that it was just the Pokeball, without all the spinner parts.
The button is unchanged. The center piece is really just simplified, it is now just a simple cylinder basically. The hemisphere is cut to allow the center to fit in.

The pokeballs on his spinner look much nicer than the one I printed, so look at his for a better picture. The proportions are the same so this should like just like his when printed.

I estimated the size of this, it is about 40mmx40mmx45mm. Print at 2x size for a more realistic Pokeball

The hemispheres print in about 15 minutes each(print 2, one white, one red). -no supports needed but do it if your printer can't bridge well.
The center takes about 15 minutes as well.
The button takes around 2 minutes.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Notes:

I had to print the button a bit smaller to get it to fit.
Also, TheDesignerd suggested supports on the hemisphere for his model but I printed it fine without them as long as it is oriented like an igloo.

author: Bocefuss4500

title: Transformable Dremel table saw / disc sander / shaper

description.text:
Update 12/13/17: Added a storage spot for the Router Support Plate under the left and right Flex Holder Table. Uses two 10mm M3 screws.

This is a transformable and adjustable rotary tool based table saw / disc sander / shaper for use with the Dremel Flex Shaft attachment. The Flex Shaft should fit most rotary tools, but be sure to check.

Lets you:

  • Mount cutting discs to perform straight or angled cuts thin wood, pcb's, screws, plastic parts, etc of any length.
  • Mount sanding dics for disc sanding.
  • Mount sanding drum or grinding bits in the shaper configuration for spindle sanding/ grinding.
  • Mount other bits for other operations that I haven't thought of.

The Flex Shaft is available here: https://www.amazon.com/Dremel-225-01-Flex-Shaft-Attachment/dp/B0000302Y8/

The table saw is inspired by https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:670704, but I wanted to be able to cut materials of any length without being limited by the size of the rotary tool. The Flex Shaft is small enough that you can get unlimited length cuts when using standard 1-1/2" cutting discs, so I built my design around it.

Using a 1-1/2" cutting disc, gives you about a 4mm cutting depth. If you need a deeper cut or want to use a smaller disc you need to raise the shaft up, which limits the total cutting length. Also, I don't recommend doing deep cuts in anything but softer materials like balsa or plastic because you are likely to hit the stall torque of the shaft.

The height of the blade is fully adjustable, this not only lets you adjust the cutting depth, but also lets you mount other tools like sanding disks or drums.
( sanding disk as pictured is available here: https://www.banggood.com/2-Inch-50mm-Hook-and-Loop-Sanding-Pad-14-Inch-Shank-with-60pcs-100-to-2000-Grit-Sand-Paper-Kit-p-1089070.html )

Also you can rotate the Flex Shaft 90 deg to use it as a spindle sander, shaper etc. I've not tried it with routing bits, so I can't comment on how well they work.

To secure the table, use clamps or m4 screws through the tables feet holes. If you do choose to use screws, note that the outer feet holes are arranged in a 96mm wide square so that you can rotate the table as needed.

Finally, you can extend the table's length by printing table extension's and extra Main table foot pairs.

Note that the table was designed for and printed in abs. Pla should be fine, but I have not tested it.

The main table needs to print with supports, but everything else should be supportless.

Assembly instructions/notes:
(see Assembly Drawing pdf for reference and parts list)
Print the following:

  • 1 Cutting plate
  • 1 Main table (be sure to use supports carefully due to it's mid-air holes)
  • 1 L flex holder
  • 4 Flex holder table foot
  • 1 Main fence
  • 1 Miter gauge slider
  • 1 Dremel flex holder
  • 2 Flex holder plate
  • 1 Miter gauge
  • 2 Main table foot 1
  • 1 Miter gauge wall
  • 2 Main table foot 2
  • 1 R flex holder table
  • 1 Router support plate
  • 1 Cutting plate 2
  • 10 M3_scroll_wheel (see https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:670704 for the file)

For assembly you will need the following hardware:

Note that there are minimum and maximum quantities for some screws. The table has a number of superfluous holes, these are to give some flexibility in how tightly you secure the table and the flex holder. The minimum number is the amount I use (three screws for each flex holder plate, two to attach the main and flex holder tables, and none for the main table feet)

  • 1 screwdriver for driving M3 screws
  • 15 - 29 M3 x 10mm screws (at least three with pan heads for the cutting plate and the miter gauge)
  • 2 M3 x 12mm screws
  • 0 - 16 M4 screws (length depending on your workbench thickness)
  • 0 - 16 M4 nuts
  • 35 - 49 M3 nuts (incl those for the scroll wheels)

Assembly should be fairly straight forward using the drawing as a reference. I'll outline some steps below:

Note that I printed everything in abs so I abs welded parts together instead of gluing.
For gluing I recommend epoxy, you might be able to use superglue, but for the table feet it might be too weak.

  1. Glue M3 nuts into the cutout holes in the Flex holder plates, Router support plate, and Main table
  2. Slide and glue the Flex holder plates into the slots in the Dremel flex holder, be sure to get the orientation correct. The ends with two pairs of screw holes should be facing the hole in the Dremel flex holder. Make sure the plate's are as flush as possible with the top of the Dremel flex holder.
  3. Glue feet onto the L and R flex holder tables and onto the Main table
  4. Mount the Dremel flex holder between the R and L flex holder tables. Secure it by using inserting a minimum of three M3 screws per side through the slots in the R and L flex holder table. You can adjust the Flex holder's height by loosening and re-tightening the screws.
  5. Assemble the miter gauge using M3 screws, it slides into the slot on the main table.
  6. Everything else either slides or screws together, see Assembly Drawing pdf.

You can transform the table into shaper mode by removing the screws from the Dremel flex holder, rotating it 90 deg (so the Flex shaft points upward), and re-inserting the screws
Then mount the Router support plate by inserting screws into the unused slots and extra holes in the R and L flex holder table.

Disclaimer: This tool is to be used at your own risk. I am not be responsible in case of injury or improper use of the table. Remember to be cautious; do not try to push the table,
or the Flex Shaft past it's limits.

This is a collection of parts used on a model Springer pusher tug. The kort nozzle is posted as a separate part on Thingiverse.

The hull and deck of the boat are not 3D printed. The deck and bottom are made of 1/8" plywood. The sides, bow and stern are made of 1/2" plywood. The pdf drawing file shows the overall design with dimensions. The txt file shows the profile of the sides.

The deck is supported by a pair of 1/2" thick cross members located as shown in the drawing. The Post.stl is mounted in the center of the aft cross-member. The forward fenders are attached to studs in the forward cross-member.

The pusher fenders are made of three parts - bump frame, bump cross and bump flex. One bumper cross is printed with a pair of mirror-imaged bumper frames. The bumper flex was printed using a "Flexi-Dually" so the the rigid frame and flexible fender are printed as one piece. However, the flex fender is optional and can be left out if you don't have the dual extruder capability. The mirrored frames fit snuggly on the bumper cross piece. There are holes in the bottom of the frames designed to fit onto studs on a structural cross-member near the bow. the exact location is shown on the pdf drawing.

The helm super structure is divided into separate .stl files to enable printing without supports. Once printed, the pieces can be glued together using CA glue. A floor for the superstructure can be used to hide and opening into the hull. The roof and walls can be sanded smooth, then painted.

The ladder, life preserver, navigation lights, exhaust pipes, radar and radar supports can be glued onto the sides roof. The anchor light hand rails are made of brass tubing cut and soldered as shown in the picture.

Hope you can use some or all of these pieces.

A separate posting shows gripper arms that can be mounted on the model boat to deliver and retrieve model buoys that are also posted elsewhere.

print_settings.Notes:: The platform ended up curling a little at the corners, at 205°C with the 60°C heated bed and Inland black PLA. I'm sure I could have added a raft, or "mickey mouse ears" in the corners, but I figured I'm probably going to be reprinting this at the new size anyway, so....

title: Shelf System - All Inclusive - 25mm - 140mm
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
*** NOTE: I put "How to Assemble" text in the Post-Printing section below.

*** Edit 6 Jun 2017: I've uploaded the new, 165mm version of the shelf system here:

https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2368917

I have a lot of space at the top of my desk's hutch. I used a few headphone hooks for my 25mm top, and they work great, although I wanted a safe place to store my calipers. With space at a premium, I thought to myself "I wonder if I could design a shelf from scratch, that hooks to the desk like the headphone holders, but has a platform?" This is that design.

It works great, but when I put my caliper box on the platform, it could probably use another inch back. Take a look at the depth of the platform (140mm) and the width (110mm), and if this is enough for you, great!

I will most likely be uploading a newer version of the platform that's 165mm in depth, so I don't feel like my caliper box is going to slide off the back.

Will most likely be making a tweaked/improved version of the brackets, so the center of gravity is a little improved.

As with any desk hooks, if these are a little too big, try using some stickers on the inside of the bracket where it contacts the top and/or bottom of the desk's shelf (like a shim). Some of the headphone hooks I've printed needed a very thin sticker (or no sticker at all), while others needed a more puffy sticker (maybe a millimeter in thickness) to keep it from sliding off.

If there's any interest in different configurations - like wider openings than the 25mm, or different size platforms, just let me know. This was to scratch an itch of mine, and I designed and tweaked it in about a week.

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

Creator Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

Medium

Infill:

60% (screws) / 30% (everything else)

Notes:

The screws printed at 30% ended up being a little fragile. As it is, 60% infill on the screws ended up giving me one broken screw where the tip broke off a little due to tightness while screwing things in. That was my fault. 30% for the brackets and base works out fine.

The platform ended up curling a little at the corners, at 205°C with the 60°C heated bed and Inland black PLA. I'm sure I could have added a raft, or "mickey mouse ears" in the corners, but I figured I'm probably going to be reprinting this at the new size anyway, so....

Screws

I designed this with Fusion 360 with the built-in screw library, and created the "Phillips-head" on one end of the screws using geometry. It's just a plus. Works great with my Nest screwdriver I had kicking around. I don't know the official designation of this screw, but I was shocked I got it so close to specs. The screw gets a little brittle near the end with the cross, so maybe print the screws at an even higher infill? Or just be careful screwing them in. They should only screw in halfway, and no further.

How to Assemble

First things first - there are pictures. Look through them. They might help answer any questions you may have. If something's not clear, just ask in comments. I'd be more than happy to help.

1) You'll need to clean up the parts, just like with any other 3D printed object. If you're printing with rafts or supports (not necessary, but YMMV), you'll have to clean those off first. When I first printed the brackets, I ended up letting Simplify3D create supports, and it made these cute little "squiggly" pieces of plastic inside each of the holes. Easy to get out. The second time I printed, I forgot to enable the supports, and everything worked out fine, I guess. Again, YMMV. Clean everything to a level you feel comfortable with, but especially the areas like the screws and screw holes. They need to be functional.

2) Insert a screw ONLY into the front-most hole on each of the brackets. You won't be able to assemble this correctly (as designed/printed) if you put screws into the back two holes yet. Screw the screws in until they are halfway. If it feels like you're fighting it early on, you may have it cross-threaded. Try again. If it feels like it's fighting you further in, make sure you aren't closer to the halfway mark. Use one of your other remaining screws to gauge. It really won't go in more than halfway. Further than that and you'll probably break the screw. If you do that, print more screws, and try to back out the broken one safely with a screwdriver or a pair of vice grips. If you break it off cleanly/flush against the end, you'll probably need to reprint that part. Sorry.

3) Once you have the single front screw in on each bracket (the front is the "pointy"/"V" part of the bracket - look at the pictures provided) sticking halfway out, you can now screw the platform onto each side. The "top" of the platform has no holes. The "bottom" has four openings. You want to screw one bracket onto the appropriate (left/right) side of the platform. Once it's as snug as it's going to get (don't force anything!), you can screw the other bracket onto the other side of the platform. NOTE: You may have to back the screws out a little, or screw them in more, into the brackets, in order to get things to line up properly. I had to fiddle a little bit to get things flush. It should be fairly close on both sides.

4) Once you have the platform connected to both brackets by one screw on each side, it's now time to gently lift the platform up (don't break anything, don't force anything), so you can screw in the other four screws. The screws should, again, go halfway into each bracket hole. Once they are halfway in, and all installed, you can gently lower the platform down onto the screws, and everything should be flush and level.

5) Install the platform on your shelf/desk, and adjust the bracket by installing shims. I like thin and/or puffy stickers, as they're cute, and secret little hidden things that only I know about. Plenty of craft stores sell them.

6) If you're feeling really adventurous, you could probably glue things together, but honestly, I wouldn't worry about it.

If you're trying to support an object that is slightly longer than the platform, that's fine. But after a certain point, it will most likely slide off the back. I'm thinking of making a slightly longer platform. Please let me know in comments if you're interested in a custom-ish version.

Fusion 360 and Simplify3D

I used Fusion 360 to develop this from scratch, and Simplify3D to slice it up.

Using Fusion 360 and parametric design is awesome, because I can have different versions, and just tweak things in the parameters section, in order to adjust sizes, depths, and distances. If you take the time to learn parametric design, it eventually becomes a lot easier, and it makes it a lot easier to create different versions, and make improvements, later on.

title: MP Select Mini Bowden Tube Aligner

description.text:
I was having a problem when my MP Select Mini reached close to the top of the Z-axis where there was a lot of sideways pressure on the Bowden tube and fitting, which caused under-extrusion. I mixed this up and it has really helped with the issue. You need two M3 x 6mm screws to help secure the piece to the Bowden fitting.

Be advised that different manufacturers of the fittings have slightly different diameters of the blue release ring. You might need to adjust the diameter of the lower portion of the piece.

EDIT: I've added an updated version 2 that incorporates 2 M3 nuts to provide a more secure mounting.

description.text:
I found all of the flavoring holders on here to be somewhat lacking in that none (at least that I could see) were designed to be modular. As an avid ejuice mixer, I'm always getting new juices, so having an organizer that is prepared for that is an important feature.

This is a modular ejuice flavorings holder for bottles from 10ml to 30ml, assuming they are "standard" sizes. Each shelf is able to rotate freely and the design allows for adding additional shelves/columns in the future when needed.

I've tested the following bottle manufacturers; others should work too, these are just the ones I have on-hand:

TFA/FA (10 or 30ml)
INAWERA (10ml)
LorAnn (10ml)
Hangsen (10ml)
FW (10 or 30ml)
CAP (13ml)

No raft, brim, or supports should be required. Print 1x Pedestal + 1x End Cap, and as many columns and shelves as you like.

Everything is designed to be press-fit, so no extra tools or hardware should be required, but know that I printed these in "fast" quality on my Lulzbot Mini so tolerances may be off if you print in higher detail, I'm not sure. I have an issue with my printer printing ever-so-slightly out of round circles as well, so again, YMMV when it comes to the fit. For me, everything snaps into place, and the end cap should be a little loose so that it can be removed if needed.

Also, feel free to print your own end cap, I'm no industrial designer. Any 15mm cylinder will do when it comes to mating with the top of the last column, just make sure you cover a 42mm diameter to prevent the last shelf from wobbling/coming off.

Hope you enjoy!

Notes:

It may not make a difference for your printer, but I got better print quality with 0% infill on the shelves.

author: adanadhel

description.text:
You're probably thinking "What is Superflex posting this useless thing for?" Well yes, in and of itself it is entirely useless but.can be used to replace screws when designing to hold boards with common 3mm holes. Now there are others like it I know but 3d printed PLA wouldn't be your first pick to make it to the finals if you were building circuit board standoffs. I tried various designs but printability (spellcheck informs me I have just invented a new word) and elasticity of PLA poses some unique challenges. This design attempts to take into account both of these elements and appears to function well for at least one cycle of mounting a board. The standoff when pressed into the hole marginally deform uniformly in the process as opposed to totally relying on elasticity of two narrowly formed sides as others do. This more common method falls painfully short when printed in PLA. Behold the lowly PLA standoff. Less significant than the merits of two vs single ply toilet paper but hopefully also quite useful.

To accommodate for forces in the direction of shear; lateral board movement in parallel to the face of the board, I recommend framing the outer edge of the board in your design. This could be in the form of corners, sides, or a complete perimeter around the edge of the board. If you elect to frame the entire outer perimeter you may want to incorporate a slot or two cut in the frame to allow the insertion of a flat head to pry the board off the stands should you want to remove it in future. The frame could also be slightly returned to interference fit over the top face of the board to assist with shear forces and retention. The combination of snap down standoffs and a perimeter frame should provide a relatively robust mounting solution which eliminates the requirement to use nuts and bolts altogether.

I have linked one of my designs here for a MOSFET mount showing it in a practical application:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2369923

title: LCR-T3 Case - Remix
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I found this posted here - https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2066610 - but I am pretty sure that this is actually the same design posted here - https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:896665 - two years ago. In any event, I found several issues. One, the lip around the bottom was too flimsy - it detached very easily from the rest of the case with little force. This, too, was thickened and the angle of the overhang was increased to add additional support . Secondly, the battery "clip" exhibited the same flimsiness. This, too, was thickened to add additional support. Thirdly, the top right-hand screw hole was enlarged and attached to the case just like the other two for additional support. Finally, with the battery endstop in it's current position, the battery is unable to drop down into the holder with the thick, hard plastic connector (as opposed to the thin connector used on most 9v battery equipment) made into some testers. This was moved 4mm. This provides a snug fit without having to break that tab.

For those whom the other cases work fine, this offers no reason to change. For those who have issues with the original(s), perhaps this may help.

Printer:

Tevo Tarantula

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

As opposed to the recommendations of the original, I highly recommend the use of 100% infill. The additional filament usage is negligible and the added support is more than worthwhile.

Some years ago I bought a caterpillar composed of
hexagonal nuts welded together. It was made by Rock Creek Metal Craft. Rock Creek is still in business - see www.rockcreekmetalcraft.com - but now makes more elaborate art work. Hex_caterpillar.stl is an openSCAD version of a caterpillar made from pierced hexagons. A second caterpillar model, caterpillar.stl, uses only spheres and cylinders. It is meant to resemble a great peacock moth caterpillar. Both openSCAD programs are semi-parametric and one can change the size and placement of the caterpillar parts to perhaps make something more pleasing
Hex_caterpillar.stl prints better with external support.

description.text:
CREDIT:
I borrowed the trucks from here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2165853

NOTE: i edited the trucks so that they would fit together easy, the original has NO clearance and most print heads are .4mm thats 16 thousands of an inch, 8 tho on either side of your designed line, therefore you must leave at least 0.008 inches on either side of an object for press or slip fit parts. i gave you total 250 thousands but remember this is in 1/8 scale so scaled down it works out fine.

Otherwise i designed it in sketch up based on an N scale model shown in the pictures.

the file provided is an exploded version IN 1/8 SCALE you will need to scale it down, (i did 0.15 for the model shown and it ended up O scale but 0.166 would be the correct scale to O scale) and then split it up it into parts in your slicer, I use cura and i right click the part and select "split object into parts" everything you need to print will be there.

Enjoy.

prusa mendel i3

description.text: A six sided die (d6), just composed of the axis

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Notes:

The die is composed of four parts, plus a smal square dot that should serve as a pip. You can print this square in any color you like to create a contrast with the die, or just leave the cubes open, if you wish.

I designed this six sided die from scratch. The idea was to create a simple, low cost and effective die. This version is composed of the pieces to print in a 3D printer, but the original die it is suppoused to be cut in a laser cutter on a 3 mm. MDF board.

The design of the die was done using Inventor, and then it was modeled on AutoCAD 2017 to create and export the .stl files for a 3D printer.

comments.text: This is a pretty terrible design for a die considering it can land on what would be the corners of a traditional d6. Have you printed this and actually tested it to see how often this occurs?
comments.author: lpacphantom

comments.text: As I said in the comments, it is intended to be cut in a laser cutter on 3 mm. MDF. I haven't tried on a 3D printer yet. Nevertheless, I cutted, assembled and tested the wooden model, and it works pretty well, much better than you would imagine. The times it lands on the corner are very very few, and rolled in a padded surface, worked flawlessly. On the other hand, its simplicity and low cost are its assets, this allows to include this model in any board game laser cut board. Cheers!

description.text:
Very basic way to extrude 1.75mm filament through a hot glue gun nozzle for touch up and fixes. No idea if it will work but it just occurred to me that it could potentially work.
Basically you would insert the filament between the two halves and then insert the whole into the back end of the glue gun, where the glue would typically go, this allows the trigger to push the filament through as if it were glue.

Print upside down with no supports.

Printer:

Folger Tech 2020 i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Print upside down.

comments.text: I guess I'm not following how this will push just the filament without pushing these printed pieces as well.
comments.author: pwmodder1027

comments.text:
Other glue guns are likely different but for the one I have it does push the plastic pieces too while clamping around the filament, but then when you release the trigger the glue stick ring pulls the printed parts back to the starting position.
Like I said I have no idea if it would work or not, just a thought. Thanks for commenting!
comments.author: pwmodder1027

comments.text: thanks, I'll take another look at mine.  May just print this out.
comments.author: WatchitPrint

comments.text: Cool, let me know how it works out!
comments.author: pwmodder1027

comments.text:
I guess it could work, but you need a hot glue gun with a adjustable temperature...
There are two types of glue gun low and high temperature
Low=110-120°C
High=190-210°C
comments.author: Tig3rch3n

comments.text:
Hey thanks for commenting, sorry I just now saw this.
Mine has a temperature adjustment on it that goes up to ~220 which is just enough for PLA. ABS is definitely out of the question though.
I saw those 3D pens and though, you know what the only difference between that and a glue gun is the material diameter essentially (and I'm sure much more flow control).
Thanks!

title: FliteTest (FT) TJ's Gremlin Upper Frame and Camera Mount

description.text:
NOTE: It has been discovered after a crash that the camera-retention zip tie is located such that it pushes on one of the super-tiny surface-mount resistors on the WolfWhoop WT03 camera. If you crash just right, the resistor might be broken off, severely affecting the performance of the camera. The leading theoretical solution at this time is to place a bit of foam [tape] under the zip tie or use some potting compound to protect the surface-mount components.

This part was designed as a replacement upper frame for TJ William's FliteTest Gremlin frame, specifically using the Wolfwhoop WT03 camera, however its since been discovered that this frame also works for a Lumenier AIO-200 if you mirror the design (I'll make separate files for each later, but in the meantime you can just mirror the file in your printing software. Special thanks to aaronaltounian for helping figure it out!). I designed it for three reasons:
1.) I wanted the circular polarized antenna on my quad to be protected from landing (read: crashing) upsidedown
2.) I bought a FrSky X4R-SB 3/16 receiver in order to have the telemetry features (which I DID get to work), but didn't realize until later that it didn't quite fit in the stock frame WITH the camera inside the frame...
3.) I wanted to!

Camera has a 10-degree pitch. If there's interest for more/less aggressive angles or no antenna shroud at all just so you can have the extra space under the frame for electronics, I can easily produce variations on this design, so leave a comment if you'd like it modified in a specific way!

Version 3 needs screws to hold the upper frame to the lower frame and glue or double sided tape to hold the camera to the upper frame.

Version 4 uses zip ties.

This design is realistically a work-in-progress as I improve the design for strength and weight reduction, so expect to see variations on this frame design as the spirit moves.

Printer:

Printrbot Simple Metal

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.15mm

Infill:

25%

Notes:

Leave fan on during print.
Recommend using flush-cutter pliers for trimming some of the supported areas, but your printed might be better tuned than mine and not need as much post-production work.

LINKS

https://store.flitetest.com/power-pack-g-with-flite-test-gremlin-frame/
https://store.flitetest.com/frsky-x4r-sb-3-16-channel-receiver-w-sbus/

This camera was selected because the power output is switchable between 25mW/50mW/200mW. I made a rough model of the camera to make sure that it would fit correctly, and included the model so other people can use it if they need/want to.
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B06XB2ZRBP/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o02_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

Other stuff

Feel free to take the model and modify it however you like. I only ask that you post a picture on Thingiverse. Not because I want credit - I want to see where people's creativity leads them, and want to see cool things!

Version 4!

Version 4 has been released! This version is designed around the idea of using little zip ties to hold the upper frame to the lower frame, and one mini zip tie to hold the camera onto the upper frame. There are channels inside the frame to accommodate the zip ties.

Pictures will be added once I get my replacement lower frame in to replace the one I crashed.

When printing the foot take the Left STL file and mirror it to create the Right. Make sure and print it laying on the side so no supports are needed. The pedal brackets are specific to the pedals I am using but are not required if you want to use velcro or other attachment means.

description.text:
This is a remix of @TheGoofy's awesome loose filament spool. I needed something for Push Plastic Sample Filaments that's 200g per coil [https://www.pushplastic.com/collections/sale-1/products/pla-color-packs] and couldn't find something that I could print with my MP Select Mini V2 (120mm squared plate). This really extends the forks/arms to make the spool sized for 8" coils and a little thicker to account for the extra weight.

Update 6/16: Added a curved spool spike to hold the filament in better. Print five, no supports needed, 0.175 for on the MPSM.

Update 6/26: Added "Extended Loose Spool Fork_V2_easier_fit.stl". It cuts down on the fitting prongs so it could fit better into the disk. Print this for easier fitting else you might have to trim the first one to fit if your printer isn't extremely accurate.

I also recommend printing this Raised Spindle Holder (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2370342) if you have a MP Select Mini V1/V2 and want to use this spool with your stock spindle holder.

description.text:
Remix of a previous spinner that required a ceramic bearing. This one doesn't spin as long, but it should go for 30-45 seconds without too much effort. It accelerates more than the previous version since the magnets have more travel without the bearing to get in the way. It requires a few flicks to spin it up since it slows down when the magnets move to the outer position.

Inspired by example prints I saw from whosawhatsis's book, 3D Printed Science Projects*.

Atomic Filament Clearance Translucent Ruby Red PLA and Filamentum Vertigo Gray PLA*

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=swua50XJmQY

*affiliate links

Printer:

Eustathios

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Infill:

100%

Notes:

0.4mm extrusion width recommended

Uses 10mm diameter rare earth magnets*, which come in a variety of thicknesses - The thinner magnets allow for more configuration options, using more magnets should result in transitioning at higher speeds.

Superlube oil* or similar - I usually disassemble it after printing and a few minutes of break-in, then add one drop of superlube into each of the pivot points.
Here's the design file if you need to make any adjustments to the tolerances, etc: https://cad.onshape.com/documents/33a28fa59ba204bb3a1306d4/w/5d553ff0b7ec85cfe29740a9/e/43834d9d41c851f0266f0326

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/6qC0bP5mirn
Dust boot attachment for a 75mm spindle (like the one found in the shopbot buddy).

Every so often the screw flange on the top of the Z-Stage would loosen the bolts and cause problems. This would result in a varience in the z offset this resulting in bad prints. And those nuts are really small and hard to tighten. So I wanted a better solution than every so often tightening those nuts. 
This cap will fit over the flange and allow you to attach it with a few M3 bolts. You will have to drill some holes on the top of the z stage.

Print off the part. Make sure it fits well. I tried to make it as snug as possible. 
Drill through the holes on the part and attach with 3 3M bolts and nuts. I attached mine with bolts that were 16 mm long and they just barely work. I suggest at least 20 mm but if you are like me you have a bunch of 16 mm left over from the construction of your bot.

title: Enable unlimbited gauntlet with Cello bow holding attachment

description.text:
This was designed with the help of Team Unlimbited (http://www.teamunlimbited.org), and can be printed and assembled by following their instructions. A video of it in use can be found here: https://youtu.be/LmcIhVnmvjw

The big difference is the hand, which has no fingers. The hinge can be completed with a piece of filament as the pin, just use something hot to make the ends slightly bulbous so it doesn't fall out. Better to use 3mm for the hinge pin, 1.75 will be a bit loose (but also works in a pinch).

The cover to the bow holder snaps shut.

One small thing: The person this was made for plays the cello mirror image of other cello players. It is possible you may need to move the rod that goes in the bow frog for a standard cello player.

Iteratively, with the end user

Lots of details here http://www.megankhofmann.com/uploads/5/6/7/3/56734939/p1769-hofmann.pdf

Design was supported by the leaders of the Unlimbited arm group, as well as students at Carnegie Mellon and Faculty at Carnegie Mellon and the University of Washington.

author: Trdolan03

description.text:
The pegs on this board are compatible with standard LEGO bricks.
There are 25 x 25 pegs (200mm square).
I was amazed that it printed so well and worked the first time. Bricks stack on it perfectly-- not too loose or too tight.
The plate is completely flat on the bottom.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

40%

Notes:

LEGO compatible plate 200mm (~8inch) square, with a 2mm thick plate. I have also included a .8mm (or "Thin") version to print faster, with the idea that it gets glued to a table-- I expect the "Thin" version will be easy to break, unless you're going to support it. I only printed the original version and it works great (see image).
25 pegs in both directions. If there is enough interest, I might put in the effort to try it out as a customizer part, so you can set how many pegs you want in each direction.

More Settings Details:
I used the concentric infill pattern to keep the support uniform for all pegs, and it took my printer about 8 hours.
In case you are worried about printing size, I added a small version (4x4) for a quit-printing part that won't use up much filament. You can print this first and then scale as desired for a tighter or looser fit.

description.text:
So after built my fantastic aquaponics system, and introducing some dumb, but very cute tilapia fingerlings into the tank, I started finding my drains into the grow beds getting clogged.

After staring down the pipe, I notice eyes peeping back at me. Apparently the little guys got sucked right up into the inlet and got stuck at the valve!! Can't let that happen!

So shopping at Home Depot yielded very unsatisfactory results, so I just rolled my own.

These grilled endcaps fit standard 1" and 3/4" PVC pipes. So now the fish are happy and I'm happy.

Notes:

I print in ABS at 80% infill for strength.

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jwkLfaLH5B4
http://www.flickr.com/photos/scottmayson/7299304934/in/photostream

Print-out, 0.3mm layers, the Front and Back housings add required components and watch your tweets etc print out and tear them off. There are other grate projects for this to print the weather, appointments etc.

This is printed on a Ultimaker with a 0.6mm nozzle and heatbed with Kapton tape.
The back housing requires some internal support! Print with CURA and crack the support out with a flat blade screwdriver. Try printing it either on its base or open-front on the platen.

I had trouble printing this with ABS as it lost dimension in the Z-axis due to shrinkage so, a new version will apear with different supports and print orientation for ABS & clip retaining details to keep the front face better connected.

title: Fidget spinner for small children 608ZZ remix

description.text:
Cut a hole for a standard 22mm 608ZZ bearing, it will not sit flush so a raised cap will be needed

13mm M8 bolt per original design but needs to be 13mm or less for flush fit or if you want to use the bolt as a "set screw" to lock in the bearing then just a little over 13 will be fine

I printed mine with 3 shells, 100% infill (its a small print so it won't use much plastic)

Very small so little kids can use it easily

-edit-06/11/2017 created a M8 threaded rod (standard pitch) and a 5/16" UNC threaded rod and placed in the holes (I don't have a tap set and was unable to force screwing in the bolt on the one w/o threads) [untested as of yet] tested...did something wrong...the threads are not round..correcting

print_settings.Notes:: Depending on your printer and its configuration, you may consider printing the main body with or without fillets, and changing the orientation of the caps to be printed with or without supports. Due to the concavity of the caps, I found it best to print them shafts-down with support material for the tops. That way the visible dimple is clean and smooth and any irregularities as a result of the supports are hidden by the main body of the spinner.

description.text:
This is designed to work with 5/8" steel balls; they should just pressure-fit snugly into the outer holes. The center accepts an R188 bearing for optimal performance; I was able to get this to spin for 3:25! The caps can either be pressure fit or glued together depending on the tolerance of your printer, there's only about a 3mm overlap between the male and female parts so i found it best to use a bit of CA glue to hold things together.

The steel balls are heavy, and give this spinner a lot of rotational inertia. It's very high performance, and a blast to use!

Printer:

Folgertech FT-5

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.1-.3mm

Infill:

15-35%

Notes:

Depending on your printer and its configuration, you may consider printing the main body with or without fillets, and changing the orientation of the caps to be printed with or without supports. Due to the concavity of the caps, I found it best to print them shafts-down with support material for the tops. That way the visible dimple is clean and smooth and any irregularities as a result of the supports are hidden by the main body of the spinner.

I love lzyperfection's Kodama model, but found that it didn't stand well, especially with its oversized head filled with popcorn kernels to create a rattle effect. To fix this, I made a base for this little rascal to stand on.

Included are the original split file (which allows you to add BBs, pebbles or kernels for the rattle) as well as an assembled Kodama if you don't want that feature.

UPDATE: If you are having trouble with the assembled Kodama (see binou80's comment below), try the "kodama-together-4_fixed.stl" which was sent through Netfabb.

remixed_from.author: ZestyTech
remixed_from.title: Mockup of the Zesty Nimble: Lightweight direct drive extruder

description.text:
Nimble mount for a Rostock Max V2 by SeeMeCNC with the PEEK Hotend.

See https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2184991 for firmware settings.

Rotate and print with supports. Or, if you really want, skip the supports.
6/6/17 -- Reworked a bit, removed the thin wall. Id still like to add some material below the worm gear for the nimble, but maybe later. Ive also included the entire hotend (before the nimble stuff) as an iges, so people can make stuff with it if needed. SeeMeCNC has some of the files available (the effector and nylon ball ends), but most of the specific ones are not, ie the PEEK Hotend.

For this, youll need to remove the PTC fitting on the top, pull the hotend apart, and replace the PTFE liner with a longer one, which will be cut off after the top is installed.
Added some step by step pics...
Rip the sucker open, remove the old PTFE liner, add new long piece, thread everything on, put the orange piece on, add the nut, add the yellow piece, mount it to the effector, and slice the PTFE tube off.
Done.
Also, add the captive nuts for mounting the nimble.
Your hotend may separate on the bottom of the PEEK portion, thats fine. Thats where mine did the first 5 times i opened it up.

author: SparkyFace5

description.text:
First off, let me please ask that if you like these designs and find them useful please do like, follow and share my content. And if you have any ideas or concepts to modify the content I would love to hear!

These are some great little Volkswagen trinkets that those with the VW love wouldn't mind dangling from their rear-view mirror, their keys or bag or just see your printer write out those memorable words :)

This is a model of the E3D hot end from E3D-Online.com This was modeled using exact dimensions from the documentation here: http://e3d-online.com/Documentation for V4 E3D. This is modeled as the 1.75mm bowden heatsink. If there is demand, direct drive and/or 3mm models can be generated Note: New V5's have a smaller thermistor for the semitec in a slightly different location

comments.text: You say a 3mm or direct drive version could be made?  Would you mind uploading or linking to such a version?  I'm new to 3d printing, just ordered a prusa i3 style printer and really wanting to get multiple extrusion set up soon.  This, with the kraken quad extruder setup thing, looks promising but I need something for 3mm.  I was also looking at a few different filaments that don't support bowden style extruders.  In the future I hope to be able to make changes like these myself but so early on I don't want to waste time just to get a messed up end result.  Thank you for considering!
comments.author: FirebirdTA01

comments.text: Yeah that's not a problem. Is there a particular reason you require that kind of accuracy? Just curious as there's very little changes between the 1.75 and 3mm so for modeling purposes it wouldn't have much difference.
comments.author: FirebirdTA01

comments.text: Yeah, I plan on trying to build an extruder like this using lost pla casting but I would want it to work with 3mm filament, not 1.75.  It would be a project to turn this model into a working extruder but challenges are something I enjoy and increasing the size of my tool collection is always something I'm looking to do.
comments.author: mkelly

comments.text: I would strongly advise you not to use casting for the heatsink. The inside channel needs to be perfectly smooth and with lost pla casting you'll be left with the ridges from the printing. You'd need to bore this out to the precise diameter.
comments.author: FirebirdTA01

comments.text: It can be cast then drilled, I don't have access to any lathe or mill, that is why I wanted to get a 3d printer.  Its better than nothing.  Just because somethings been cast doesn't mean it cant be finished with other tools.  I'd still like the model if that's perfectly alright.  I'm somewhat adept at 3d modeling but all my experience is in artistic models for games and such so I don't know if they would slice nicely.  Thanks for the advice and I'll update you on how the whole process works out.
comments.author: mkelly

comments.text: Sure, I can help you with that. Though I still don't think you want to use a stock 3mm version. I'd recommend I make you one with excess material for you to machine into. The top is easy and just needs a straight bore, but the bottom requires a M6 tap I believe.
comments.author: FirebirdTA01

comments.text: That would be perfect, thank you very much.  Sorry my replies have been infrequent and delayed but my plate has been full so to speak.  I'm just about finished with prior obligations though so I should become a more active member soon.  Thanks again and I'll follow your advice, just let me know when you can upload that model!
comments.author: mkelly

author: XoquE

title: RC Flying Wing (In progress)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
I'm designing and building a 3D printed flying wing. 650mm wing-span, designed to be run with 22xx motors. I'm planing something special and going to try packing a 4s 5000mah+ battery system inside this.

(Edit: Initially I was intending to use 18650's and design a removable slot to spread two of the 18650's into the wings. Quite a lot of school stuff has come up since starting this project - I'm shifting from any ambitious experimentation with batteries for the lols towards just getting this made to fit a 1000mah lipo first. Once it's up and running then I'll work on batteries in wings etc.)

If anyone's interested in progress, do let me know. If there's any features that you would perhaps like to see, please indicate as well. I am a poor student so donations are always welcome and even small amounts go a long way

Expected timeline:
(Edit : The timeline has gone to shit. I'll be resuming this project after 27 July. The stuff that I have managed to finish are under ticks ✓ )

June 5-7
First second and third design iterations (this is second design)
CFD ✓
Wing test print ✓
Flaperon design ✓
Motor housing design ✓

June 7-14
Internal wing support structures as well as cutouts for carbon support beams ✓
Housing for servos (need to finalise placement as well as movement)
Battery mount housing, battery circuit design
FPV camera housing + some solution for internal mounting

June 14-21
Settling wiring electronics + flight stability + mixing
Test flight

I agree the winglets could be tapered, but also swep back, which will help to shift their active area back and substantially improve directional stability (which could be a pain in case of flying wings). Nice to look at, looking forward for maiden flight!

A quick and dirty Astartes Marauder Interceptor proxy model for Epic scale games (40k or armageddon etc)

[update 20171021: ran all pieces through netfabb]

intended to maintain the same stylistic feel as the thunderbolt.

requires glue to assemble, but have included a 'one-piece' model so you can see it assembled. should be better with paint.
[post-print note: the model is quite a heavy beast, so i used a dab of epoxy glue to reinforce the connection from the stand to the underside of the hull after the superglue had set.]

decided against pulling apart all the turrets and gribbles from the body as there shouldn't be too many overhanging pieces that aren't part of the main support structure.

An ancient astronomical instrument used in navigation - More complex ones also had mathematical functions.
I'm interested in making precision devices with my makerbot and this seemed like a good place to start - This is version 1, if it prints OK then I will progress with other versions with more features (such as a circular slide rule)
I'm posting the sketchup files in case anyone would like to modify, or improve the design (I'm new to 3d modeling so it's pretty crude)

This model is untested.
Warping may be an issue with such a large flat object.
2 STLs, 1 for the main disk, and 1 for the center peg and the observing arm.
This is a replacement capacitor plate for the AC Voltmeter Heathkit.

If you are missing the capacitor plate inside the AC Voltmeter Heathkit, then you can use this file to have a plate laser cut or cnc'ed! For ours, we laser cut a melamine plate, and attached one of the outer capacitor lugs to the case for grounding it properly. In order to ensure we had the correct laser settings to cut through the melamine, we did a few test rectangles first. A better idea would be to use actual metal for the plate, as that is what would be included in the kit. For more information on this Heathkit please see: http://www.evilmadscientist.com/go/heathkit-part1

description.text:
I have been printing a few spinners for my son and daughter found here on thingiverse.
Now it was time to try designing one by myself.
It's using a standard 608 bearing and 3 M10 nuts.
It's a bit bigger than most spinners. Not for small hands.

I opened the bearing cleaned it with benzin. The result was astonishing.
This spinner kept on going for 3 minutes and 15 seconds :-0

I use the caps from this spinner by @Mr_MinerAl
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2315392
They work really great and lock nicely in place with no need for glue.

Printer:

Mini Fabrikator

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

15%

Notes:

Print speed 40mm/s

Glue in the nuts to make sure they will stay in place.

You might need to trim the hole for the bearing, depending on the accuracy of your printer, to make the bearing fit.

comments.author: Bryan_S

comments.text: I tried to print this multiple times, and it only worked after repairing the model at https://netfabb.azurewebsites.net/. You just upload your .stl file, it gets repaired, then you get the fixed .stl file. It's awesome!
comments.author: sierrapelton

comments.text: I'd like to see two adjustments made: 1) making it more solid (for gamers), and 2) making one that prints well scaled to 22mm (standard die size for RPG games). Otherwise, it's a pretty decent model! (Any tips for removing the raft?)
comments.author: zaayrdragon

comments.text:
yeah, i know i have to look into the solidity problem. tbh, i don't know what happened and i haven't had time to look, yet.
could you tell me what the 22mm refers to? is that something like the distance between opposite corners?
... and with "prints well", do you just mean overall scaling or were you thinking of having other parameters changed?
anyway - thanks for the feedback!
comments.author: zaayrdragon

comments.text: is it possible that you upload a two color version of this? I want to print it, but with two colors...
comments.author: injoi

comments.text:
I'm not sure how to do that tbh.
And where would the different colours be?
comments.author: injoi

comments.text: I was thinking that the circles with the numbers could be the second color. Oh The way I would go about it is to take the original model then delete everything except the circles with the numbers. This way the original dice and the circles with the numbers have the same reference frame. This would mean there are two stls, one with the bulk die and one with the numbers
comments.author: ikiko

comments.text: cool, i'll try that!
comments.author: injoi

comments.text: My makerbot seems convinced that this is hollow and no amount of infill will change that. Is there a program where I can change that? If not, could you up load a file that is not hollow? Thanks!

Simply take out the Ashtray and it will fit in there just nicely.
With this you can make a movie where you went and record the GPS data.
The Bicycle -VDO i used also shows speed, average speed, elevation, time,
temperature and more using GPS. No cables needed!

Once you arrive you can take out the complete assembly and put the ashtray
back in. So it looks original again.

title: Longest Drive and NTP Golf Competition Markers

description.text:
I designed this as I have semi regular golf competitions with my friends and wanted to add some extra fun by having some novelty prizes! We thought we would include longest drive and nearest the pin.

I had fun designing these in tinkercad and used M3 bolts and nuts to attach the paper and clear plastic. I am really happy with how they came out, I am open to suggestions.

I have actually forgotten what settings I used for the print, fairly sure .2mm layers but any settings should work ok. I got it to pause at the right layer height and changed the filament from black to white so the lettering stands out. I used PLA but should work in ABS too.

Here is a link to the paper sheet that you can print out: https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/142MPYZXwp9pXU7t1uB91VLIm8HTW3h2yuCbUn2Xipfk/edit?usp=sharing

comments.text: Be aware, the extra clip piece is NOT located on the print bed.  You have to separate the pieces and drop that piece down to the print bed before slicing.

author: cheetahkid

description.text:
I made this HBP to use with my Rep2 While my 2x was down in order to avoid losing some business. I started with my 6.2"x11.2" Aluminum build platform which I usually use with my Rep2 and had my friend who is a CNC programmer machine a dish to house the 6"x8" PCB which now sits level with the aluminum platform, in the bottom left corner and can be taped over. It plugs into an independent 12V 8A power supply. It heats up to 100-110C in less than 2 minutes and holds the temperature steady without putting any extra load on the machine's delicate electronics. Cons of this setup: Does not support a glass plate on top The current electronics configuration doesn't support a variable temperature, however, a potentiometer could easily be added. Pros of this setup: HBP with full Rep2 build area
<10 second installation/uninstallation
Flip it over for a full perfectly flat aluminum plate
Removable unlike 2x I priced out the upgrades for the 2 available methods: MBI wands $200 shipped for a 2x HBP plus a $150 Power supply upgrade The other option (with limited availability) costs $175 for the plate, $150 for the power supply upgrade, and another $150 for the nearly mandatory Z-arm upgrade. This has worked well for me, but I lo longer need it. I figured I could pass it on to someone who needs it more than me. In the early days of my Rep2, I quickly discovered how quickly the need for a HBP becomes apparent. Keep in mind this is a homemade product and may require a sense of adventure to use and calibrate properly. The cost of parts and labor to build this was $216.94 and I'll let it go for for $149.99 shipped and I'll throw in a roll of Kapton tape so you can be printing ABS, Nylon, T-Glase and more in 2 days or less! I'll get some pictures added very soon, I just wanted to type this up in a wave of motivation. Cheers! Link to eBay listing: http://www.ebay.com/itm/261342412327?ssPageName=STRK:MEUNSOLD:IT&_trksid=p3984.m1560.l2649

This is a generic handle with no screw holes that I made for a porch net door which is relatively light. I attached the handle using a good double-sided glue tape, and it works great.
The side contours fit nicely in the hand when using the handle

The design is basically a cube with a cylinder lying on the top, and the sides shaved off using bigger cylinders.

The dimensions of the handle are set as parameters.

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/elA1Sx4PW5w

I wanted a Cable Drag Chain that was easy to remove the cable from without having to un-thread it. I edited BikeJunky's Design (I Hope he does not mind) to create this design.

I created this one to use cable ties (Size 140mm x 3.6mm) to hold the cable in place. You do not have to use a cable tie on each link..

I have a video of this cable chain in action on YouTube at https://youtu.be/5ASePrkYNLA
